So if only we had had a consul at Rome,⁶ the Senate, while honouring you with marks of high distinction, would have formally expressed its gratification at what you have essayed to do already, and are preparing to do in the future. But the time for these amenities, so far from having gone by, is not, in my opinion at any rate, even yet fully ripe. For I always think that the only true distinction is that bestowed as a free gift upon men of mark, not in anticipation of their future

services, but in recognition of their conspicuously good work in the past.

For this reason (so but there be any constitution 2 left where it is possible for honour to shine forth), take my word for it, you will have more than enough of the most splendid honours heaped upon you. But that honour, which can truly be so termed, is not an incentive for the moment, but the reward of a long career of consistent excellence.
